Appendix B: Taking Babies Home After Death ( Documentation for Patient's Maternity Healthcare Records ........................................................................................ 13
Appendix C: Taking Babies Home after Death Appropriate form for parents ............ 14
Introduction
To ensure that staff are able to offer and advise bereaved parents when they want to take their baby who has died (either before or after birth) home, and to facilitate the process.
To ensure all legal processes are adhered to and fully documented in the mother's healthcare records.
Equality impact assessment
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to the provision of a
service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix E)
Scope
This policy should be read in conjunction with the following guidelines in relation to the management of patients with pregnancy loss:
Guideline for the management of patients with pregnancy loss; registration number 09042;
Guideline for the use of mifepristone and prostin in a termination of pregnancy for fetal abnormalities or intrauterine death; registration number 06032;
Child Death and Rapid Response Policy; registration number
Roles and responsibilities

The Specialist Nurse for Guidelines and Audit is responsible for ensuring clinical policies, guidelines and SOPs, are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The clinical director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the directorate.
The Head of Midwifery, maternity matrons and maternity managers are responsible for ensuring maternity staff are aware of the guideline and implement it.
The Obstetric Clinical Lead Consultant and Labour Ward Lead Consultant are responsible for ensuring the implementation of this guideline within the clinical setting.
All maternity staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to  implement this guideline.
Introduction
5.1. When babies die before, at or after birth the usual course will be for the baby to be transferred from the hospital by an undertaker for burial or cremation.

If a post-mortem is being undertaken, the baby will go the hospital performing the post-mortem and then return to Broomfield Maternity Unit after the examination and then transferred to the undertakers

Parents should be offered the chance to take their baby's body home prior to burial or cremation. And in the case of babies under 24 weeks gestation some parents may express the wish to bury / cremate their baby's body themselves.

Given the various possible complications involved (i.e. in relation to legal issues of disposal, deterioration of the baby's body and the potential distress involved which parents may not have anticipated) this request requires sensitive handling and knowledge of legal / environmental issues identified in this policy.
Exceptions to the guidance
This guideline does not apply in cases when the coroner is involved.

If parents wish to take baby home after the coroner's investigation, the coroner's permission would have to be sought and also that of a Rapid Response Investigator if the death is being investigated under the Child Death Review and Rapid Response Policy (08071)

Parents who request post-mortem examination on their baby/babies should be advised that a post-mortem should be undertaken before their baby is taken home. If parents wish to take their baby home after the examination staff will need to explain how their baby's appearance may be altered after the post-mortem procedure.
Babies born before 24+0 weeks

(Refer to guideline for ‘Management of patients with pregnancy loss; registration number 09042. ‘Guideline for the use of mifepristone and prostin in a termination of pregnancy for fetal abnormalities or intrauterine death'; registration number 06032)
It is not a legal requirement for babies born with no signs of life before 24+0 weeks of pregnancy to have a funeral, however it is usual practice to offer parents such a service.

For a funeral to be conducted a ‘Medical Certificate of Examination' (Form 1C) must be completed by a doctor, and this form should accompany the baby to either the hospital funeral directors, or an undertaker of the parent's choice.

If the baby is for cremation by an undertaker the parents will also need a cremation form (Cr1) to meet legal requirements (form completed and sent to the Undertaker by the maternity administrative coordinator; extension 3345).
(Refer to guideline for ‘Management of patients with pregnancy loss; registration number 09042)

It is possible for the parents to take a baby of this gestation home and bury or cremate it without official status. However, it must be documented in the patient's healthcare records that the parents understand the following:
They must own the land and title deeds where they bury the body;
The burial / cremation must be recorded in any deeds for said land;
The local environmental agency must be informed of proposed burial / cremation in case of contamination of any underground water routes, drains etc;
The family should be advised to consider how they would feel if they had to leave the land where the baby was buried / cremation;
Parents may wish to consult with the hospital chaplain or their local faith representative to discuss suitable service options;
Parents have signed an official release form for their baby's body
(Refer to Appendix B);
Parents need to have received the appropriate written information from the hospital (Refer to Appendix D).
Stillborn babies or neonatal deaths

(Refer to guideline for ‘Management of patients with pregnancy loss; registration number 09042. ‘Guideline for the use of mifepristone and prostin in a termination of pregnancy for fetal abnormalities or intrauterine death'; registration number 06032).
Parents of stillborn babies (over 23+6 weeks at time of death) have a legal duty
to bury or cremate their baby using the services of a registered undertaker.

Failure to do so is an offence and staff must ensure and document that parents who take their babies home have made appropriate arrangements; this could involve producing documentary evidence i.e. a letter from an undertakers.
Parents must have signed an official release form for their baby's body. (Refer to Appendix B)

If staff have any reason to believe that proper arrangements for the burial/ cremation for the baby are not going to be made they should not release the baby's body to the parents; and should contact the Trust's legal department on extension 4664.

For stillborn babies parents require the Certificate of Stillbirth to obtain a Certificate for Burial / Cremation form (green) from the Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages (RBDM) which they should be instructed to give to their chosen funeral director if the baby is not returning to the hospital. If the baby is for cremation they will also need Cr . (Cr3 will also be needed and be completed by maternity administrator on extension 3345; Cr13 will be completed by the funeral directors).
(Refer to guideline for ‘Management of patients with pregnancy loss; registration number 09042)

For neonatal deaths parents require the Certificate of Neonatal Death to obtain a Certificate for Burial / Cremation form, from the RBDM, which they should be instructed to give to their chosen funeral director if the baby is not returning to the hospital. If the baby is for cremation they will need Cr4, Cr5 and Cr10 completed by two doctors.  (Cr1 will be completed by the maternity administrator on extension 3345 who will send it to the undertakers who will care for the baby. (Refer to guideline for ‘Management of patients with pregnancy loss; registration number 09042)

For communication purposes the labour ward co-ordinator and maternity administrator on Ext 3345 should be informed that a baby is at home. And a copy of the taking baby's home forms and the funeral arrangements form should be kept within the maternal notes

The community midwife or bereavement midwife team should be contacted, and a home visit should be arranged the following morning to ensure that there are no concerns. The community midwife also needs to be informed if there is any further paperwork to complete.
Practical advice for parents
As stated above parents should be aware of what legal documentation they require and their responsibilities for ensuring appropriate arrangements for disposal are made.
Emotional implications should be discussed regarding themselves and other family members.
They should be offered chaplaincy services to discuss funeral arrangements before discharge.

They should be prepared for the changes in their baby's appearance over time, especially if baby is kept in a warm, brightly lit, environment. Consideration must be given to weather conditions or central heating. They should be aware that their baby may be fragile to handle and that gentle cotton clothing or sheets are advisable.

Parents may take a Flexmort cuddle cot home with them to keep baby at the recommended temperature and to slow the natural deterioration of the body. Parents must be shown how to use the unit and have a copy of the instructions. They will also need to take a container of de-ionised water to use with the unit. Please inform the bereavement midwife team.
The parents should be advised that their baby is not left alone with small children or pets.
Parents should be given a copy of ‘Taking your baby home after death - information for Parents'.
(Refer to Appendix C)
Informed decision to take baby home
After receiving all the information, parents who wish to take their deceased baby home must have the following points documented and a copy of all forms issued kept in the maternal notes.
Parents have the necessary documentation for an undertaker if they are not returning their baby's body to the hospital (see section 4 and 5 below).
Parents have a letter, with hospital contact details, explaining that their baby had no signs of life on discharge and the plans for burial / cremation / return to hospital. (Refer to Appendix A)
Parents have been advised on the care of their baby's body, emotional issues for themselves and other family member and expected deterioration when not in a cooled environment.
There are no public health risks (i.e. the baby had no infectious diseases).
If the parents plan to bury / cremate a baby that is under  weeks gestation they are aware of all landowner / public health / emotional issues. (Refer to Appendix D)
Transporting the baby home

Baby's being taken home before burial or cremation should be dressed as the parents wish and wrapped in a shawl. They may be carried in their mother's arms or placed in Moses basket. A car seat may also be used for term or near term babies and there is a car seat for families to use if needed.
If parents are travelling a long distance then a coffin should be purchased from the undertakers or they may wish to contract an undertaker to transport their baby to their destination.

If parents are transferring the baby to another country it will be necessary for any legal registration to be undertaken with the RBDM and a certificate for burial / cremation obtained. Parents will need to liaise with the funeral directors of their choice and a suitable container purchased to transport the body. Any carriers i.e. airlines or ferry companies would need to be contacted and staff should speak to the local coroner in Essex for further advice.
Training requirements
All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes dealing with bereavement
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Guideline Management

12.3.1 As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Infection prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
Professional midwifery advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Audit and monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance
Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Safety Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group and appropriate Maternity Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
References
Department of Health (2006) Care and Respect in Death: Good Practice Guidance for NHS Mortuary Staff
Child Bereavement Trust – www.childbereavement.org.uk
J Schott, A Henley, N Kohner (2016) Pregnancy Loss and the Death of a Baby – Guidelines for Professionals 4th edition. SANDS.
ARC – Antenatal Results and Choices www.arc-uk.org
